topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jackie Bavaro, her books, and the episode’s focus on product strategy and career growth.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Flatfile and Amplitude.

topics.title: Jackie’s path into product and Asana
topics.summary: Jackie shares how she discovered PM via a Microsoft internship, got rejected then accepted into Google’s APM program, and was recruited to become Asana’s first PM—leading to writing her interview books.

topics.title: Writing to learn and demystify interviews
topics.summary: They discuss how Jackie’s own interview struggles and observing candidates’ patterns motivated her to write publicly to level the playing field and clarify what interview questions really test.

topics.title: Early Asana mistake: saying no too fast
topics.summary: Jackie recounts an early-career misstep of reflexively shutting down ideas, how feedback from her boss and coaching helped her reframe suggestions as problem signals, and how “saying yes” improved collaboration.

topics.title: Using coaching effectively
topics.summary: Jackie contrasts ongoing coaching vs. targeted coaching, explaining she prefers coaching for specific growth goals and noting how coaching can sometimes inflate small issues.

topics.title: Why Jackie stayed at Asana and grew
topics.summary: Jackie explains staying through uncertain periods because of growth opportunities, and describes how she earned a seat in high-level planning meetings to learn company-building and strategy beyond features.

topics.title: Manager burnout and the hidden downsides
topics.summary: They discuss the loneliness and constraints of management (confidentiality, misaligned incentives), why many still want to try it, and treating management as a reversible “two-way door.”

topics.title: IC vs management tracks and impact
topics.summary: Jackie argues you don’t need endless promotions to earn well, highlights salary realities (e.g., senior PM), and explains why true top-level IC roles are rarer and often platform/partnership-focused.

topics.title: Defining product strategy: vision, framework, roadmap
topics.summary: Jackie shares her evolving understanding of “strategy” and presents a three-part model: an inspiring vision, a strategic framework (market, success, big bets), and a roadmap as a feasibility check—not a commitment.

topics.title: What makes a good strategy: connecting dots
topics.summary: Jackie explains that numeric targets aren’t strategies; good strategy links business goals to product choices through explicit assumptions and intermediate decisions, and improves via repeated communication and spotting confusion.

topics.title: How to get better at strategy
topics.summary: She recommends collaborative strategy work, learning through repeated decision-making and outcomes, and cross-applying frameworks from other domains (e.g., consistency vs. comprehensiveness) to unlock new perspectives.

topics.title: When to focus on strategy as a new PM
topics.summary: Jackie advises new PMs to spend the first ~6 months learning the product and executing existing strategy, then draft strategy in focused blocks; repeated feature-level disagreements often signal missing strategic principles.

topics.title: Career growth advice and early-career pitfalls
topics.summary: Jackie’s key career tactic is asking managers what to build toward a future promotion to focus feedback; she also recommends early-career time at larger companies for fundamentals and warns against over-engineering narrow starter projects.
